title-group.article-title: Explaining Temporary and Permanent Motor Vehicle Theft Rates in the United States A Crime-Specific Approach

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Aki Roberts is an assistant professor in the department of sociology, University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee. Her interests include quantitative methods, crime clearance, National Incident-Based Reporting System (NIBRS) data, Japanese crime, police networks, and motor vehicle theft.

Steven Block is an assistant professor in the department of Criminology and Criminal Justice at Central Connecticut State University. His primary research interests include crime data, crime prevention, and motor vehicle theft.

sec.title: Objectives:
sec.p: To apply crime-specific models based on differing potential offender pools and opportunity structures to temporary and permanent motor vehicle theft (MVT).

sec.title: Method:
sec.p: Using 310 U.S. cities with 50,000 or more residents, the current study developed and examined crime-specific multivariate models for temporary and permanent MVT rates. To evaluate the distinctiveness of crime-specific variables’ associations with each MVT type, the study also predicted each MVT rate via measures theoretically specific to the other.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Among temporary-specific variables, young male population and the percentage of households without a vehicle were positively associated with temporary MVT. Permanent-specific measures of adult male property offender pool size, percentage of households with high disposable income, unemployment, U.S.-Mexico border proximity, and auto-related businesses were associated with permanent MVT (though in an unexpected direction for disposable income). Some variables were associated with both types of MVT, but young male population was uniquely associated with temporary MVT while unemployment rate, distance to U.S.-Mexico border and number of auto-related businesses were specific to permanent MVT.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Findings suggest that specific prevention approaches are needed for each type of MVT. Shortcomings of the research include potential misclassification of temporary and permanent MVT and lack of some potentially important opportunity variables.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Analysis of a measure that combines different crime types involves, as Copes (1999) suggests, an implicit assumption of common causes for those different crime types. However, opportunity-based theories argue that each type of crime has a different opportunity structure, and encourage researchers to undertake crime-specific analyses in which different factors are posited to influence measures of different crime types (Felson and Clarke 1998). Motor vehicle theft (MVT) is one specific legal category of crime that has been studied through this opportunity-based perspective. Still, opportunity-based analysis of MVT may require even greater specificity, because MVT can be categorized into two quite different types (Felson and Clarke 1998; Maxfield 2004). Some MVTs are committed for temporary and nonprofit-oriented personal needs, including joyriding and short-term transportation. Others are committed for permanent retention purposes, including resale, export, or dismantling for spare parts (Clarke and Harris 1992a, 1992b; Copes and Tewksbury 2011; Felson and Clarke 1998; McCaghy, Giordano, and Henson 1977). These differences suggest that temporary and permanent MVT may have different potential offender pools, targets, settings, and opportunity structures. If so, a crime-specific approach may be needed to explain the rates of these two types of MVT, with different opportunity-based explanations employed for temporary and permanent MVT. But to date researchers have, with relatively few exceptions, generally treated MVT as a monolithic crime type, using the same set of explanatory factors to explain all kinds of MVT incidents (e.g., Copes 1999; Potchak, McGloin, and Zgoba 2002; Rice and Smith 2002; Saville and Murdie 1988).

The current study develops and tests crime-specific models for temporary and permanent MVT in the United States, using city-level data on rates of recovered and unrecovered thefts per 100,000 vehicles constructed from the Uniform Crime Reports’ (UCR) “Property Stolen and Recovered” file. The current study also explores the distinctiveness of crime-specific variables’ associations with each type of MVT. This crime-specific focus is especially important when formulating effective and appropriate prevention strategies for different types of MVT (Cornish and Clarke 1986).

sec.title: Opportunity Theories and Crime-Specific Approach
sec.p: The crime-specific approach draws on ideas of opportunity structures embedded in immediate situational surroundings that are crucial to opportunity theories (Felson and Clarke 1998). The routine activities approach, one of the most popular opportunity theories, argues that differences in crime rates across time and space result from differences in the supply of likely offenders, suitable targets, and capable guardians. In practice, this approach has emphasized the latter two factors, while simply assuming a constant flow of likely offenders (Cohen and Felson 1979). However, other researchers have argued that there is variation in the presence of likely offenders across different times and areas and that this will result in variable risk of crime victimization even when holding constant levels of target attractiveness and guardianship (e.g., Bennett 1991; Miethe and Meier 1994; Rice and Smith 2002). The rational choice perspective, another popular opportunity theory, attempts to explain “how the offender makes crime choices, driven by a particular motive within a specific setting, which offers the opportunities to satisfy that motive” (Felson and Clarke 1998:7; see also Cornish and Clarke 1986). Together the routine activities approach and rational-choice perspective seek to explain how macro-level opportunity structure shapes an offender’s decision making and leads to a particular type of crime (Felson and Clarke 1998).

In contrast to traditional theories’ lack of emphasis on the specific forms of crime, opportunity-based theories recognize that different opportunity structures exist for different types of crime, and call for the development of crime-specific models (Clarke and Felson 2008). Opportunity theorists further believe that different opportunity structures can apply to incidents falling under the same legal offense definition. According to Felson and Clarke (1998:14), “In general, the opportunity for crime must be evaluated for very specific categories of offense.” As an example, they noted that, from the perspective of opportunity theory, robbery is not one crime but many, depending on the setting and type of victim, and that even finer differentiation will often be required by the theory. Felson and Clarke (1998:14) acknowledged that “some opportunity principles may fit all crimes. But even these need to be applied taking into account the specific crime setting and modus operandi.” Furthermore, a potential offender’s characteristics and life circumstances influence how he or she perceives (and/or responds to) criminal opportunity structure, and hence also influence the particular crime committed by that offender (McGloin et al. 2007; Wright, Pratt, and DeLisi 2008). This suggests that different potential offender pools exist for different crimes, even within the same legal offense category (e.g., Thomas, Dichter, and Matejkowski 2011).

The concept of different opportunity structures and potential offender pools within a legal crime category is important for understanding MVT. Temporary thefts are intended to satisfy temporary personal needs such as entertainment, short-term transportation, or means to commit other offenses. Permanent thefts are committed for purposes of resale, export, or dismantling for spare parts (Clarke and Harris 1992a, 1992b; Copes and Tewksbury 2011; Felson and Clarke 1998; McCaghy et al. 1977). In the next sections, we explore the differences in potential offender pools, targets, settings, and opportunities for the two types of MVT.

sec.title: Crime-Specific Potential Offender Pool for Temporary and Permanent MVT
sec.p: Previous research findings indicate differences in the characteristics of temporary and permanent MVT offenders, suggesting that the pool of potential offenders may differ for those two types of MVT. As with other street crimes, MVT offenders are predominantly male (e.g., Arizona Criminal Justice Commission 2004; Corbett 2007; Mullins and Cherbonneau 2011), but temporary MVT offenders tend to be younger than permanent MVT offenders (Herzog 2002; McCaghy et al. 1977). McCaghy et al. (1977) reported that joyriders and offenders seeking short-term transportation tended to be teens and were much younger than profit-oriented offenders. Tremblay, Clermont, and Cusson (1994) found that the percentage of 15- to 19-year-old males in the population was positively associated with temporary MVT rates and that decreases in the young male population explained the general decline in temporary MVT between 1976 and 1988. In Herzog’s (2002) Israeli study, vehicles stolen by younger offenders were more likely to be recovered, indicating that theft for temporary use was relatively more common among youths.

Because successful permanent MVT requires planning, skills, and social connections, as well as sensitivity to changing law enforcement initiatives and demand from black markets (Clarke and Brown 2003; Resendiz 1998; Shane 2010; Tremblay, Talon, and Hurley 2001), it calls for the involvement of older and more experienced offenders (Mullins and Cherbonneau 2011). Most permanent MVT offenders have prior criminal records (Tremblay et al. 2001), and some transitioned from temporary to permanent MVT as they aged (Moffitt 2003; Slobodian and Browne 1997, 2001; Tremblay et al. 2001). Tremblay et al.’s (2001) study in Montreal showed that offenders in the local resale, local parts chopping, and export resale networks tended to be in their 30s; the oldest were found in export resale networks, perhaps reflecting the more complicated process of exporting stolen vehicles. McCaghy et al. (1977) noted a similar mean age for profit-oriented MVT offenders, and Herzog’s (2002) work in Israel found that vehicles stolen by older offenders with prior property crime convictions were less likely to be recovered, suggesting that thefts by older, experienced offenders are more apt to be for permanent retention purposes.

sec.title: Crime-Specific Targets, Setting, and Opportunity for Temporary and Permanent MVT
sec.p: Temporary MVT offenders tend to choose easy and accessible targets that are readily available in their surroundings (Herzog 2002; Kriven and Ziersch 2007; Tremblay et al. 1994). Clarke and Harris (1992b) found that the majority of the most vulnerable vehicles for temporary use theft in the United States were commonly available American models, while exotic models such as Porsches were less often stolen by temporary MVT offenders. On the other hand, permanent MVT offenders’ pursuit of financial gain requires that they consider illegal market demand and profit potential when targeting vehicles for theft (Brown 2004). MVT for illegal export purposes often involves very expensive luxury cars, whose high price helps compensate for the costs and risks associated with a complicated transaction and transportation process involving many parties (Tremblay et al. 2001). The Highway Loss Data Institute’s (2008) analysis of county-level insurance data found that the average loss per claim was much higher in counties near the U.S.-Mexico border or with major ports (e.g., Miami-Dade), implying that more expensive vehicles are targeted for illegal export. However, very expensive and exotic cars are less desirable in local fencing markets: Affluent local consumers generally do not search the used car market for bargains, and attracting less affluent consumers with large discounts on luxury vehicles might raise suspicion (Tremblay et al. 2001). Instead, local fencing and auto parts markets demand middle-range vehicles that are favored by typical consumers in the used car or parts market (Tremblay et al. 2001). In any case, permanent MVT offenders target relatively expensive vehicles, because inexpensive vehicles are less attractive for both local and foreign black markets. Clarke and Harris (1992a, 1992b) showed that few of the top 20 models for permanent MVT were inexpensive.

In addition to differences in targets, temporary and permanent MVT stem from different settings and opportunities. Because at least some temporary MVT is committed to satisfy practical transportation needs, temporary MVT should decrease as more juveniles gain access to a household vehicle (Tremblay et al. 1994). Tremblay et al. (1994) found a positive association between the percentage of households without a car and temporary MVT in Quebec and explained that decreasing percentages of households without a vehicle (i.e., increasing access to household vehicles) during 1963 to 1988 led to a decrease in temporary MVT.

In contrast, permanent MVT is facilitated by demand from local and foreign black markets. Poor economic conditions that make consumers, especially the economically disadvantaged, more willing to buy stolen vehicles and parts may in turn encourage local fencing markets (Tremblay et al. 1994, 2001). Also, cars stolen in the United States constitute a substantial proportion of those sold or traded in global black markets (Miller 1987). Stolen cars can be driven across international borders, transported in ferries, or shipped out of ports in sealed containers (Clarke and Brown 2003; Miller 1987; Resendiz 1998). Previous studies have found strong and consistent evidence of a relationship between international black markets and permanent MVT. Miller (1987) showed that Texas border cities had higher percentages of unrecovered vehicles (suggesting relatively more permanent MVT) than did cities in the state’s interior. Similarly, San Diego County’s southern sections had a much lower recovery percentage than did its northern sections (Plouffe and Sampson 2004). Roberts (2012) also found that closer distance to the U.S.-Mexico border or international ports decreased the likelihood of swift recovery.

Permanent MVT often involves counterfeiting or dismantling for major parts before sale in local and foreign black markets (Tremblay et al. 1994, 2001), and requires appropriate premises for those activities. Although chopping for major parts sometimes takes place in less formal settings such as residential garages, counterfeiting and dismantling are conducted to a substantial extent in otherwise legitimate auto repair establishments (Mullins and Cherbonneau 2011; Tremblay et al. 2001). Such establishments have the necessary equipment and a continuing supply of legitimate targets for body switching, and it is hard for the police and consumers to detect these illegal activities in the context of legal businesses (Tremblay et al. 2001). In a similar way, legitimate auto and parts dealers can easily obscure sales of counterfeited vehicles and chopped parts to unsuspecting consumers (Brill 1982). Fierce competition leads a relatively large proportion of legal auto businesses to engage in at least some illegitimate transactions (Brill 1982; Clarke and Brown 2003; Tracy and Fox 1989; Tremblay et al. 2001). By providing appropriate premises for these illegal activities, legal auto-related businesses may promote permanent MVT.

sec.title: Current Study
sec.p: The research findings discussed above suggest that temporary and permanent MVT differ in potential offender pools, targets, settings, and opportunities. While MVT offenders of all types tend to be male, the potential offender pool for temporary MVT includes inexperienced youths, as opposed to the older and experienced criminals who are likely offenders for permanent MVT. Temporary MVT offenders seem to steal whatever is readily and commonly available around them, whereas permanent MVT offenders’ goal of financial gain leads them to target the moderately to very expensive vehicles desired by illegal markets. Areas lacking in access to household vehicles may experience more temporary MVT, while poor local economic conditions and close proximity to foreign black markets provide opportunity for permanent MVT by increasing demand for stolen vehicles and parts. The presence of seemingly legitimate auto-related businesses may also encourage permanent MVT by supplying appropriate settings (and hiding places) for illicit activities. These possibilities suggest different explanatory factors for temporary and permanent MVT and call for the use of specific models for each MVT type.

Instead of assuming a unified explanation for all types of MVT, the current study attempts to develop and test crime-specific models for temporary and permanent MVT in the United States. Most previous multivariate MVT research does not differentiate types of MVT, even when situated in opportunity-based theories (e.g., Copes 1999; Potchak et al. 2002; Rice and Smith 2002; Saville and Murdie 1988). Studies that did examine temporary and permanent MVT separately are descriptive (univariate or bivariate) and/or used data from other countries that may not be applicable in the U.S. context (Brown 2004; Clarke and Harris 1992a, 1992b; Farrell et al. 2011; Herzog 2002; Kriven and Ziersch 2007; Tremblay et al. 1994, 2001; Webb 1994). Also, some MVT studies that use recovery percentages or outcomes are implicitly limited to only permanent MVT (Clarke and Brown 2003; Field, Clarke, and Harris 1991; Miller 1987; Nunn 1993, 1994; Plouffe and Sampson 2004; Roberts 2012).

The current study addresses this need for multivariate research that distinguishes temporary and permanent MVT by applying crime-specific models in an analysis of data on MVT rates in 310 American cities with populations of 50,000 or more. In addition to examining separate models developed from distinct theoretical considerations involving temporary and permanent MVT, the current study evaluates the supposed crime-specificity of these explanatory variables by predicting temporary MVT rates via measures that are theoretically specific to permanent MVT, and vice versa. Such analysis will indicate whether or not these crime-specific explanatory variables affect only the type of MVT with which they are theoretically linked, providing a richer understanding of these potential influences on MVT rates.

sec.title: Data
sec.p: The current analysis linked data from 2006 to 2008 UCR’s “Property Stolen and Recovered,” 2007 UCR’s “Offenses Known and Clearances by Arrest,” and “Arrest by Sex, Age and Race” files, 2007 Law Enforcement Management and Administrative Statistics (LEMAS) data, the 2007 Economic Census, and the 2006 to 2008 American Community Survey. To ensure comparability of data from these sources, analysis was restricted to city jurisdictions with populations of 50,000 or more that reported data to UCR for 12 months in 2008. Ten agencies, mostly in North Carolina, reported zero MVT recovery for all 12 months. It is difficult to believe that these cities with more than 50,000 residents and fairly many (78 to 5,266) MVT incidents had no stolen vehicle recoveries for an entire year, so we assume that such data are inaccurate, and therefore excluded those 10 agencies. 1 Furthermore, 14 agencies had a trend in the most recent five years of reporting a number of recovered locally stolen vehicles that exceeded the number of locally stolen vehicles. Reporting more recovered than stolen vehicles might be possible in a single year, for example, if a large number of vehicles were stolen at the end of one year and then recovered in the early part of the next. However, it seems implausible that a jurisdiction could have substantially more recoveries than stolen vehicles for two or more consecutive years, because such a scenario would likely require a pattern of very long recovery times for many stolen vehicles. Such a pattern would be inconsistent with prior recovery research, which has shown that most vehicles are recovered within a week, with recovery after a year almost unheard of (e.g., Roberts 2012; see also Barnett 2005). Thus, we also excluded those 14 agencies from the analysis. 2 The final sample consisted of 310 cities; the complete list of cities can be provided upon request.

sec.title: Dependent Variables
sec.p: Dependent variables for the current study are temporary and permanent MVT rates for each city. Many researchers have suggested use of a stolen vehicle’s recovery status as a reasonable proxy measure of temporary and permanent MVT (e.g., Clarke and Harris 1992a, 1992b; Field et al. 1991; Herzog 2002; Maxfield 2004; Slobodian and Browne 1997; Tremblay et al. 1994). Recovery of a stolen vehicle depends heavily on the thief’s purpose, as recovery will be more difficult when a car was stolen for profit-directed permanent retention purposes. Some cars stolen for profit are given a new and seemingly legitimate identity through counterfeiting techniques, before sale in the black market (Tremblay et al. 2001) and/or export to other countries (Clarke and Brown 2003; Clarke and Harris 1992a). Others might be dismantled in “chop shops” and sold for major parts (Tremblay et al. 1994). On the other hand, vehicles stolen for temporary personal needs are more likely to be abandoned quickly and recovered (perhaps with damage). Therefore, the rate of MVT in which the vehicle was not recovered should be a reasonable approximation of the rate of permanent MVT, and a similar rate of MVT with recovery should approximately correspond to the level of temporary MVT. 3

Temporary MVT was measured by the number of recovered stolen vehicles per 100,000 vehicles available in the jurisdiction, and permanent MVT was measured by the number of unrecovered stolen vehicles per 100,000 vehicles available. 4 Here a “recovered” stolen vehicle is one that was stolen in the reporting jurisdiction and recovered there or elsewhere. That is, in measuring temporary MVT we included stolen vehicles that were recovered outside of, as well as within, the originating jurisdiction. Because cars stolen for temporary use purposes could quickly travel and be dumped in nearby jurisdictions, omitting such incidents from the originating jurisdiction’s temporary theft measure would be misleading. This would be especially problematic in metro areas with many jurisdictions. By recording recovered stolen vehicles for the originating jurisdiction, regardless of the location of recovery, we can appropriately measure temporary theft activity in each jurisdiction. As mentioned earlier, data on recovered and unrecovered stolen vehicles were obtained from UCR’s “Property Stolen and Recovered” file, with data from 2006 and 2008 averaged to adjust for yearly fluctuations. The 2006 to 2008 American Community Survey provided city-level data on the number of vehicles available.

sec.title: Independent Variables
sec.p: To develop crime-specific models, the current analysis selected different sets of theoretically informed independent variables for temporary and permanent MVT and also included as controls noncrime-specific variables measuring guardianship and arrest risk that are relevant to both types of MVT.

sec.title: Independent variables specific to temporary MVT.
sec.p: While MVT offenders of all types tend to be male, temporary MVT offenders are disproportionately young. Thus, the pool of likely offenders for temporary MVT was measured as the percentage of the population that 15- to 17-year-old males comprise. Because temporary MVT offenders tend to steal vehicles commonly available near them, higher vehicle density should increase a jurisdiction’s temporary MVT rate by providing such offenders with more potential targets. Vehicle density was calculated as the number of vehicles per square mile. Both of these measures drew on data from the 2006 to 2008 American Community Survey. We also included a measure of household vehicle inaccessibility as another variable that is theoretically specific to temporary MVT. We followed Tremblay et al. (1994) in measuring lack of access to a household vehicle by the percentage of households without a car, as reported in the 2006 to 2008 American Community Survey. As the percentage of households with no vehicle increases, temporary MVT would be expected to increase.

sec.title: Independent variables specific to permanent MVT
sec.p: MVT offenders of all types are generally male, and professional auto thieves tend to be older, and experienced enough to engage the social networks required for complicated fencing operations (e.g., Tremblay et al. 2001). Permanent MVT offenders therefore may share characteristics of the general pool of adult male property offenders, so we measured the potential offender pool for permanent MVT via the number of adult male property offense arrestees per 1,000 population. 5 Data on adult male property offenders were obtained from 2007 UCR’s “Arrest by Sex, Age and Race” file. As permanent MVT offenders generally target relatively expensive vehicles (Brown 2004; Tremblay et al. 2001), measures of the number of households that can afford such cars can indicate opportunity for permanent MVT. Using data from the 2006 to 2008 American Community Survey, the prevalence of households with sufficient disposable income to purchase relatively expensive cars was measured as the percentage of households that earned at least $75,000 in annual income and spent less than 20 percent of that income on housing.

Demand from local fencing markets and proximity to foreign black markets also likely promote permanent MVT. Economic conditions that may encourage local fencing markets were measured via the percentage of the jurisdiction’s labor force that was unemployed, using data from the 2006 to 2008 American Community Survey. Measures of a city’s proximity to potential foreign outlets were based on logged distances to 24 U.S.-Mexico border crossings, 122 U.S.-Canada border crossings, and the 61 American ports with foreign cargo value of $1 billion or more (www.aapa-ports.org). Legitimate auto-related businesses may contribute to permanent MVT by providing appropriate premises for engaging in (and concealing) illegal activities (Brill 1982; Tremblay et al. 2001), and their abundance was measured by the number of automobile/parts sales and repair establishments per 1,000 vehicles in the jurisdiction. Data on such establishments were obtained from the 2007 Economic Census.

sec.title: Nonspecific independent variables
sec.p: As theory suggests that measures of capable guardianship and arrest risk could influence both temporary and permanent MVT, such measures were included in models for both MVT types. According to Cohen and Felson (1979), guardianship includes informal supervision over potential crime targets. Previous MVT studies often used the number of multiunit structures to measure lack of guardianship, because housing arrangements such as large apartment complexes may provide relatively little informal supervision of parked vehicles and encourage all types of MVT (e.g., Copes 1999; Rice and Smith 2002; Walsh 2009; Walsh and Taylor 2007). The current analysis measured multiunit structures as the percentage of housing structures with five or more units, from 2006 to 2008 American Community Survey data.

The rarity of auto theft arrest generally leads both experienced and inexperienced MVT offenders to feel little fear of detection and apprehension by police (Copes and Tewksbury 2011). Sophisticated permanent motor vehicle thieves adopt tactics for avoiding arrest even in the face of police surveillance activities (Cherbonneau and Copes 2006; Clarke and Brown 2003; Miller 1987; Tremblay et al. 1994), 6 and younger temporary use offenders may be simply unconcerned with the police. Still, classical deterrence theory would suggest that greater arrest risk should reduce both temporary and permanent MVT (e.g., Nagin 2001), and arrest risk measures were included in the current analysis. Arrest risk variables included measures of MVT clearance, police initiatives targeting MVT directly, and police workload. The MVT clearance rate was calculated as the percentage of MVT incidents cleared by arrest in 2007 UCR’s “Offenses Known and Clearances by Arrest” data. Police activities directly aimed at MVT were measured by variables indicating whether an agency had an auto theft special unit with full-time officers, and whether it used a stolen vehicle tracking system or license plate reader technology. Police workload was calculated as the number of index crimes 7 divided by the number of full-time sworn officers. A larger police workload probably means less flexibility to allocate manpower to detecting and apprehending auto thieves, so that a greater workload indicates less arrest risk. Information on police activities and the number of full-time sworn officers were taken from 2007 LEMAS, and the number of index offenses from 2007 UCR’s “Offenses Known and Clearances by Arrest” file. Appendix A gives descriptive statistics for all variables.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: For the 310 cities used in the current analysis, mean MVT rates per 100,000 vehicles were 595.99 for temporary MVT and 313.96 for permanent MVT. The correlation between temporary and permanent MVT rates was .38 (p < .001); the modest size of this correlation supports the use of crime-specific models. For the multivariate analyses, temporary and permanent MVT rates were logged to reduce the skewness of their distributions, and White’s (1980) corrected standard errors addressed heteroscedasticity. Variance inflation factor scores were less than 4 in all models and indicated no substantial multicollinearity problems among the independent variables for all models (Menard 1995). In reporting the results, we first discuss separate models specifically developed for temporary and permanent MVT. Each of those models includes only the opportunity factors theoretically associated with the specific MVT type. Table 1 shows these results for temporary- (model 1) and permanent- (model 3) specific models. Second, we report on models that examined the distinctiveness of crime-specific variables’ impacts by applying all explanatory variables theoretically linked to either type of MVT. Table 1 also gives the results for this combined opportunity variable model for temporary (model 2) and permanent MVT (model 4).

sec.title: Temporary MVT Specific Model (Model 1)
sec.p: In the temporary-specific model, measures of the likely temporary MVT offender pool (males aged 15 to 17) and the percentage of households with no vehicle had statistically significant effects, 8 in the expected direction, on temporary MVT rates. Males aged 15- to 17-year-old are a small proportion of the total population (mean 2.09 percent; see Appendix A), but even a small increase in their population share was associated with a substantial increase in the estimated temporary MVT rate. A one-half percent increase in the young male population corresponded to an almost 30 percent increase in the predicted temporary MVT rate. 9 For an increase of 1 percent of households with no vehicle, the temporary MVT rate was estimated to increase about 5 percent, suggesting an important impact of this crime-specific variable.

The multiunit housing measure was not associated with temporary MVT rates. Among the arrest risk variables, police MVT initiatives and workload had positive effects on temporary MVT rates. Police initiatives appear important: The presence of a specialized auto theft unit was associated with 27 percent higher temporary MVT rates, while the use of stolen vehicle tracking system and license plate reader were associated with 36 percent and 20 percent higher rates, respectively. (The unexpected positive associations between police initiatives and temporary MVT are discussed in the conclusion.) For workload, the temporary MVT rate was estimated to increase by approximately 30 percent when the number of index crimes per officer increased by 5.

sec.title: Permanent MVT Specific Model (Model 3)
sec.p: As was the case for temporary MVT, the measure of the potential offender pool (for permanent MVT, adult male property offenders) was associated with permanent MVT rates in the expected direction. Estimates indicated that as the adult male property offender pool increases by 1 per 1,000 population, the rate of permanent MVT increases by 8 percent. Unemployment rate, distance to the U.S.-Mexico border, and the number of auto/parts dealers and repair establishments also were related to permanent MVT rates, all in the hypothesized directions. For each additional 1 percent unemployed, the permanent MVT rate was estimated to increase by 13 percent. Longer distances to the U.S.-Mexico border were associated with a lower rate of permanent MVT, as suggested by previous literature. Ten percent greater distance to the U.S.-Mexico border was estimated to correspond to an approximately 1 percent reduction in permanent MVT rates. 10 However, distances to the U.S.-Canada border and major international ports were not related to the rate of permanent MVT. The number of auto repair establishments was also expected to be positively associated with permanent MVT, due to these establishments’ link with fencing operations, and it appears to be an important factor: Each additional auto/parts dealer or repair establishment per 1,000 vehicles was associated with an estimated 15 percent increase in the permanent MVT rate. The proportion of households with substantial disposable income had an unexpectedly negative effect: A 5 percent addition to the proportion of households with high disposable income contributed to an estimated 14 percent reduction in the permanent MVT rate.

There was no association between multiunit housing and permanent MVT rates, so that informal surveillance may have limited importance for both types of MVT. Among arrest risk variables, only MVT clearance rate was related to permanent MVT in the direction expected by classical deterrence theory. The permanent MVT rate was estimated to decrease by 3 percent for a 1 percent increase in the MVT clearance rate.

sec.title: Combined Opportunity Models (Model 2 for Temporary MVT and Model 4 for Permanent MVT)
sec.p: To explore the distinctiveness of the variables that are theoretically associated with permanent MVT, we added permanent-specific variables (measures of adult male property offenders, households with high disposable incomes, unemployment, distance to foreign outlets, and auto-related businesses) to the model for temporary MVT, with results shown in the second column (model 2) of Table 1. R2 increased from .46 in the temporary-specific model 1 to .51 in model 2, and formal comparison via the F-test indicated that this improvement was statistically significant (p < .001). Among the added permanent-specific opportunity variables, measures of adult male property offenders and households with high disposable income were related to temporary MVT rates in the same directions as in the permanent MVT specific model (model 3). An increase of one adult male property offender per 1,000 population was estimated to increase the temporary MVT rate by 8 percent, while a 5 percent increase in the proportion of high disposable income households was associated with an estimated 19 percent reduction in temporary MVT. Unemployment rate, distance to U.S.-Mexico border, and the number of auto-related businesses were associated with permanent but not temporary MVT, suggesting that those factors are indeed specific to permanent MVT. (Note that the auto-related business measure was no longer associated with permanent MVT when temporary-specific variables were introduced in model 4 below.) When permanent-specific variables were included, the hypothesized effects of vehicle density and MVT clearance rate became apparent. The effects of other temporary-specific variables did not change (in terms of statistical significance and sign) from the specific (model 1) to the combined (model 2) model for temporary MVT.

In the same way, temporary MVT-related variables (males aged 15 to 17, vehicle density, and households with no vehicle) were added to the model for permanent MVT rates. Results of the combined opportunity model for permanent MVT (model 4) are shown in column 4 of Table 1. The increase in R2 from .38 in model 3 to .40 in model 4 was statistically significant (p = .040). Among the added temporary-specific opportunity variables, only the percentage of households without a car affected permanent MVT rates in the direction expected for temporary MVT. For each additional 1 percent of households without a vehicle, the permanent MVT rate was estimated to increase by 3 percent. Vehicle density, which was intended to measure the presence of attractive temporary MVT targets, also had an effect on permanent MVT, but in the unexpected negative direction. Young male population was positively associated with temporary, but not permanent, MVT rates, so that this variable appears specific to temporary MVT. Note that when including these temporary-specific variables, significance and signs of the permanent-specific variables’ coefficients remained as in model 3, except that effects of the measures of high disposable income households and auto-related businesses were no longer observed.

sec.title: Discussion and Conclusion
sec.p: In our crime-specific models for temporary and permanent MVT in the United States, effects of many theoretically crime-specific variables were as expected. The positive association between temporary MVT rates and the size of the juvenile male population fits with the typical profile of joyriders as young and inexperienced (Herzog 2002; McCaghy et al. 1977; Tremblay et al. 1994). Lack of access to a household vehicle was also positively associated with temporary MVT rates. Temporary theft rates were expected to increase with greater vehicle density, as offenders who steal readily available vehicles would have more potential targets in that case, but the temporary-specific model showed no such association. This association became apparent only in the combined model that also included permanent-specific variables.

Consistent with the greater age and experience of professional auto thieves (Herzog 2002; McCaghy et al. 1977; Tremblay et al. 2001), we found a positive association between permanent MVT rates and the size of the adult male property offender pool. Unemployment rate, a proxy measure for local fencing market activity, was also positively associated with permanent MVT. Permanent MVT rates increased with closer distance to the U. S.-Mexico, but not the U.S-Canada, border. While this is consistent with accounts of stolen vehicle exports from the United States to less-developed countries (Clarke and Brown 2003), past research (Highway Loss Data Institute 2008; Roberts 2012) makes the absence of an effect of distance to major international ports on permanent MVT surprising. This absence may be due to “port shopping,” in which exporters targeting specific vehicle types steal from a larger area and then travel to distant ports with minimum security and physical inspection (Shane 2010). Conversely, vehicles that are transported across land borders may typically be stolen near the crossings. The positive association between the number of auto-related businesses and permanent MVT is consistent with the involvement of legitimate businesses in professional MVT (Brill 1982; Clarke and Brown 2003; Tremblay et al. 2001). Note, though, that the auto-related business variable was no longer related to permanent MVT when temporary-specific variables were controlled.

When predicting temporary MVT rates using variables that are theoretically associated with permanent MVT, and vice versa, it is interesting that some factors directly linked to one type of MVT nonetheless help explain the other. The permanent-specific potential offender pool (adult male property offenders) was positively associated with temporary MVT rates, perhaps because the presence of many older and more experienced offenders creates an opportunity structure that teaches younger offenders (Mullins and Cherbonneau 2011). The proportion of households with no vehicle was positively associated with permanent MVT; cities with more such households may have greater demand in illicit markets for vehicles priced below conventional market value. Although effects were not seen in all models, the number of households with high disposable incomes, a target measure specific to permanent MVT, was negatively associated with both types of MVT. This result is further discussed below.

Still, some crime-specific variables were exclusively associated with one MVT type, including young male population with temporary MVT and unemployment, distance to the U.S.-Mexico border, and number of auto-related businesses with permanent MVT. With temporary and permanent MVT rates only modestly correlated, cities with much temporary MVT do not necessarily also suffer from permanent MVT problems. A city’s efforts to combat MVT therefore may need to focus on one of the specific types, and identification of factors specifically associated with each helps policymakers respond appropriately. For example, social programs targeting juveniles may have no immediate impact on permanent MVT, while policies reducing unemployment may affect permanent but not temporary MVT.

Arrest risk variables were not theoretically crime-specific, but still had distinctive effects. Police efforts targeting MVT (measured by presence of an MVT special unit, and use of a stolen vehicle tracking system and license plate reader) were associated only with temporary MVT, and in fact with higher rates of temporary MVT. This unexpected result may arise because these police efforts targeting MVT lead to increased recovery, hence increasing the apparent temporary MVT rate. In turn, one might expect that because greater MVT clearance and lower workloads (more manpower) likely also facilitate recovery, they would similarly result in increased temporary MVT rates. However, both of those variables’ effects on temporary MVT were instead consistent with deterrence. The MVT clearance rate also appeared to have a deterrent effect on permanent MVT, but other police variables were not related to permanent MVT.

The positive association between temporary MVT rates and use of a stolen vehicle tracking system could be an artifact of increased recovery under such a system, and this relationship could also reflect Clarke and Harris’ (1992a) concern that police agencies using tracking devices will disproportionately focus on thefts of expensive vehicles (that are more likely to have a tracking transmitter). This focus could make fewer resources available to address thefts of the wider range of models targeted by temporary MVT offenders (Clarke and Harris 1992a), leaving such jurisdictions with higher rates of temporary MVT than those not using tracking systems (and therefore allocating their theft responses more evenly). Temporary MVT offenders in jurisdictions using stolen vehicle tracking systems or license plate readers may also tend to abandon stolen vehicles quickly, and compensate for this by stealing more often.

These findings of both type-specific and common effects help paint a rich picture of the world of temporary and permanent MVT, but it is important to also note the current study’s shortcomings. First, the use of recovery status to construct temporary and permanent MVT rates risks misclassification. For example, some vehicles stolen by amateurs for parts-stripping can be recovered after their profitable parts have been removed and the vehicles abandoned (Maxfield 2004; Wallace 2004). In our data, these incidents would be labeled as temporary MVT despite the profit-oriented nature of the act. If information on the recovered vehicle’s condition (e.g., intact or stripped) were available, future research could consider three categories of MVT (professional, amateur parts-stripping, and temporary use). Misclassification of permanent MVT as temporary also occurs when police make recoveries from chop shops or near borders or ports, whether by chance or through “pro-active” investigation. 11 Conversely, while “truly successful burial” of a stolen vehicle is unlikely to be carried out by inexperienced temporary MVT offenders (Tremblay et al. 1994), sometimes a vehicle stolen for temporary use is never recovered (Wallace 2004). Cases of insurance fraud are another ambiguity in MVT data, 12 as is the possibility of multiple offender motives during a single vehicle theft incident (Clarke and Harris 1992b; Copes 2003). Recovery status could at best perfectly correlate with only the offender’s final motive.

Second, some important opportunity measures are unavailable at the city level. The current analysis used a measure of informal supervision over parked vehicles, but manufacturers’ and citizens’ target-hardening practices are also important elements of informal guardianship. Better vehicle security can lower MVT rates (Brown and Thomas 2003; Clarke and Harris 1992a; Hazelbaker 1997; Karmen 1981). Recent work shows that the electronic immobilizer is the most effective commonly installed antitheft device (Farrell, Tseloni, and Tilley 2011), especially when combined with other security devices such as central deadlocking and an alarm (Farrell et al. 2011). Better vehicle security probably deters temporary MVT offenders more, as they are likely less able to defeat new security innovations and less apt to use alternative theft methods such as carjacking or obtaining keys through burglary, fraud, or robbery (e.g., Brown 2004; Copes and Cherbonneau 2006; Donkin and Wellsmith 2006; Farrell et al. 2011; Kriven and Ziersch 2007; Levesley et al. 2004; Maxfield 2004). Indeed, studies in different nations indicate that immobilizers or steering column locks reduce temporary more than permanent MVT (Brown 2004; Farrell et al. 2011; Potter and Thomas 2001; Tremblay et al 1994; Webb 1994). At present, no such vehicle security measure is publicly available for U.S. cities. However, the negative associations here between the proportion of households with high disposable income and both types of MVT may reflect affluent households’ ability to purchase cars with more effective security features.

Finally, data on jurisdictions’ mixes of vehicle makes and models are unavailable. Composition (by make and model) of the vehicle pool may have different effects on temporary and permanent MVT, as different kinds of vehicles likely attract different types of thieves (Tremblay et al. 2001). For instance, joyriders may favor low- and high-performance American models (Clarke and Harris 1992b), while makes manufactured in Mexico are frequently targeted for illegal export (Field et al. 1991; Miller 1987; Resendiz 1998). Perhaps, the percentage of the models favored by joyriders may better measure the availability of attractive targets for temporary MVT than the overall vehicle density measure used here. As discussed earlier, vehicle density had the hypothesized positive association with temporary MVT only after controlling for permanent-specific variables.

If appropriate data become available, future MVT research should consider the impact of these additional variables along with those examined here. Better data on the extent and nature of local- and national-level MVT prevention programs could also enhance future studies of specific types of MVT. Still, even with the need for further work, this study’s exploration of crime-specific models for temporary and permanent MVT, and the distinctiveness of crime-specific variables, makes an important contribution to current understanding of MVT. The substantial negative consequences of MVT for victims, and society as a whole, make continued research crucial.
